Most likely reason for reversing the Y and Z co-ordinates for the Apollo CSM is that after launch and translunar injection burn it would spend most of its time pointing retrograde. It only needs to point prograde again during the trans-earth injection burn. This reduces the amount of RCS fuel used and keeps the Service Module between the astronauts and anything that might impact the spacecraft.

So the easiest explanation because I see it's hard to explain, I've watched many videos but people have a hard time explaining, is that the rocket, even if it's cylindrical it's still have a top part, a bottom part, a left and a right part and the computer on board knows that. So in order for the rocket to be able to alter the trajectory as it flies towards the edge of the atmosphere,  it's easier to roll, put it in the exact zero position, make it easier for the computer to calculate. Imagine the rocket being an aircraft with wings, a plane going upwards. It's easier for it to be perfectly aligned. But that roll isn't necessary. It helps but I'm pretty sure they can alter the trajectory with or without the roll

The reason the Saturn V and CSM had opposite axis was the astronauts were heads down on ascent but they would fly it "heads up" in space to make it easier for former test pilots to navigate.  The reason they were heads down for ascent is to put the g-forces in a positive direction, pushing them into their seats.  Positive gforces are easier to handle that the negative gforces they would experience if they were heads up.  Negative gforces force blood to your head and cause brain damage but positive push it away and you can use a g suit to compensate.

Ok,  I'm gonna use video game airplane logic, so somebody correct me if I'm wrong: The Y axis on your plane's controller only goes up and down--you push forward to go down and back to go up. When your plane is level up is up and down is down--but when you want to turn, you roll the plane so that the new "up" is the direction you want to turn in. So if you rolled  right 90 degrees and your wings were perfectly vertical--up and down--when you pulled "up" on your controller(ignoring gravity and lift, which would both just pull you "true" down) you would turn right, relative to anyone who was watching you. Thus, the only axis that you would have to deal with would be that Y axis, and minimizing the number of axes you need to control is the whole point of the roll...

You missed an important point, at least for the Saturn V. The gyroscopes in the IMU were spun up days before launch, and would inevitably suffer from precsion before launch because the Earth rotates. The IMU had a window in it to enable the IMU  to correct for this, as in "The inner gimbal also carries three accelerometers, two pendulums, and a pair of prisms. The accelerometers measured vehicle acceleration along the X, Y, and Z axes. Their outputs were used by the LVDC to measure actual vehicle motion, for the purpose of navigation. The pendulums were used to set the X axis exactly vertical, and the prisms were used to align the Y and Z axes, just before launch. The prisms reflected infrared beams sent into the ST-124 by a theodolite stationed 700 feet away from the launch pad. Commands from the theodolite were transmitted via cables to the vehicle, to torquers in the ST-124 to orient the stable platform toward the correct azimuth."

There's one more reason on manned missions that didn't get talked about: G-loading on the astronauts.  As a rocket settles in to its gravity turn, anything or anyone inside experiences a g-force pulling towards the outside of the turn.  Since humans handle g-forces better when they're pulling towards the feet rather than the head, it only makes sense to roll so that the astronauts are head-down as the gravity turn begins.

I am definitely not smart enough to be a rocket surgeon, but a thought occurred to me about an hour after I watched this video. Rockets take a curved trajectory to reach their orbit, starting vertically then eventually working to a more horizontal trajectory.

If you have humans on board, I think you would have to have them with their heads facing towards earth due to g forces. As the rocket flattens out its trajectory the top side of the rocket would experience negative g-force while the underside would experience positive g-force. Pilots can deal with around 9 positive g-force but lucky if they can deal with 3 negative g-force.

I am not sure if rockets pull enough g-force while flatting out their trajectory or not.

The Space Shuttle answer was; that it's "roll program", rolled the four (element) stack; solid rocket boosters (2); external, expendable fuel tank (1); and, Shuttle Orbiter Re-entry vehicle, all rolled together after launch to place the external fuel tank into the slip-stream of the atmosphere impinging upon the combined vehicle as it rose into the air and passed thru the speed of sound in the lower atmosphere.


The force of the wind resistance of the atmosphere below the external tank's jettison altitude, would have torn the shuttle vehicle to pieces during the ascent. Only the external tank was designed with the structural strength to remain intact as the whole vehicle system plowed through the lower atmosphere at speeds approaching 3,000 miles per hour. Well before that speed; and before Mach One (1), the "Stack" needed to assume a launch attitude that rolled the Shuttle Orbiter out of harms way, and left the tank (with its cover of insulation) to deal with the skin friction heating and trans-sonic shock taking the vehicle into orbit.
Small rockets without thrust vectoring roll to stabilize their flight path to make their trajectory straighter.  This is also why rifle bullets roll.

While it is "easier" in theory to calculate only a pitch over, the rocket's navigation system always calculates both pitch and yaw regardless of how you launch.  So it really isn't any "easier" on the rocket's nav system.  They didn't design it any differently.   It is easier on the humans watching the displays monitoring the launch.  Even analog computers from the 50s and 60s can easily handle 3 axis nav.  It doesn't require a modern digital computer.  The shuttle also rolled to deal with the lift from the shuttle's wings.  With the shuttle upside down, the lift helps pitch the rocket over.  If the shuttle was on top, you'd have to counteract all of the lift and it actually would exceed the structural limits on the spacecraft.

I kept waiting for you to mention onboard computer complexity, and finally you did give a little nod to it. but I felt it was understated in the vid, and really, it is what it all boils down to. controlling rotation along one axis makes the calculations easier, but if a computer's doing the calculations then just write a program and be done with it right? I mean, that's how the modern world works, I don't need to understand how a cellphone works to operate one, because somebody did all that work already and now it's just a tidy little package that does the things.


so, the easier calculations are important not because of a person's ability to perform them, but because of the computer's capacity to perform them in real time. the Soviet solution of aligning the pad basically eliminates the need for any onboard calculations at all, and the SpaceX tactic of doing everything onboard is a luxury specifically afforded by modern computers. so really this is underlyingly a story of the development of computing technology and strategic use or non-use of it. if my computer can only handle a tiny amount of memory, and perform a few hundred or thousand operations per second, then I want to lighten the computational load as much as possible by doing some things outside of the dynamic computational environment. the Soviet solution was essentially to do everything outside of a dynamic computational environment. and SpaceX operates in a world where multicore GHz procs are cheap, so they can basically do whatever the hell they want in the onboard computer.

Why?
Rolling allows the main rockets to adjust for changing of center of gravity, due to fuel consumption and asymmetry. Small adjustments in yaw/pitch at the right rotational angle makes up for fine navigation.
Rather than relying on small delicate mechanical movements, the computer can use fine time measurements to make adjustments. More accurate and more reliable.

Roll on the X axis? Where the heck are you drawing your measurements from? If the rocket is on the lauchpad, the Z axis is what is the height of the rocket. X is Width, Y is Length. If the rocket was laying down, or in orbit, the cylindrical circumference of the rocket would be Z and X while the length would be Y. Either way, Z or Y governs Roll. Y or Z governs Yaw, and X is always Pitch. It seems you assume that a rocket is a 2d object and not a 3d object in a 3d space.

Luv, luv, luv the channel. One quibble, though. The N1 was not in any way, by any reasonable definition, "awesome." Awesome rockets fly their payloads to their destinations. E.g., the Saturn V was an awesome rocket in that all but one of its launches were unqualified successes and the other was a qualified success. The N1 was hardly a rocket at all--it was more of a pyrotechnic device. Three launches. Three explosions. Zero for three is not awesome. It is a record of humiliating failure, which could not be a starker contrast with the glittering success of the United States lunar program.

12:13 On the Northeast Corridor rail line, the section between New York City and Philadelphia is a mostly straight shot through New Jersey and Pennsylvania, aligned northeast / southwest. But the railroad simply calls it "east" or "west" (a train from Philadelphia to NYC is "eastbound", and one from NYC to Philadelphia is "westbound"). Things do get weird though, because branch lines "retain" these directions. The North Jersey Coast Line branches off from the Northeast Corridor in central New Jersey, and runs southeast until reaching the coast. So you can be on a "westbound" train which travels southeast, or an "eastbound" train traveling northwest.

How Air Force Missileers understood the guidance system... The missile knows where it is at all times. It knows this because it knows where it isn't. By subtracting where it is from where it isn't, or where it isn't from where it is (whichever is greater), it obtains a difference, or deviation. The guidance subsystem uses deviations to generate corrective commands to drive the missile from a position where it is to a position where it isn't, and arriving at a position where it wasn't, it now is. Consequently, the position where it is, is now the position that it wasn't, and it follows that the position that it was, is now the position that it isn't.

In the event that the position that it is in is not the position that it wasn't, the system has acquired a variation, the variation being the difference between where the missile is, and where it wasn't. If variation is considered to be a significant factor, it too may be corrected by the GEA. However, the missile must also know where it was.

The missile guidance computer scenario works as follows. Because a variation has modified some of the information the missile has obtained, it is not sure just where it is. However, it is sure where it isn't, within reason, and it knows where it was. It now subtracts where it should be from where it wasn't, or vice-versa, and by differentiating this from the algebraic sum of where it shouldn't be, and where it was, it is able to obtain the deviation and its variation, which is called error.

Hi, good vid. about the roll control: actually the first mass produced ballistic missile (would it be a SRBM or a IRBM?) Had the means for roll control, given if it was not used for a roll program afaik. I am referring to the A4 or better known as V2. It had not a gimbaling engine and no control thrusters. I'd had nevertheless thrust vectoring by means of 4 Carbon blades mostly placed in the engine exhaust. Two opposite rudders can do yaw or pitch control wrt. to the reference frame of the rocket by operating them together in the same direction (like the  horizontal tail rudders on an aircraft). The roll control can be done by two rudders operate "against" each other. Thus creating a torque by introducing a spin in the exhaust jet. Afaik the redstone was also equipped with those rudders. You forgot to mention that crewed rockets also roll to manage g-forces on the crew.  Keeping the crew head-down ensures that the g-forces generated by the pitch program are positive, pushing towards their feet, rather than negative.  Humans can endure far more positive g-loading than negative, so it makes sense to keep the astronauts head-down as they fly rather than head-up.

A better example that Waterloo, IA is "California North".  In California highways run either parallel or perpendicular to the coast.  Regardless of where you are in California North / South highways run parallel to the coast while East / West run perpendicular.  This means that in Santa Barbara with its gorgeous south facing beach, US 101 South actually is heading pretty much due east.  Highway 41 which runs from Morro Bay to Yosemite passing through Fresno heads pretty much due North, but because it starts at the coast and ends in the Sierras it is an East / West Road. It is confusion like this that lead to signs like the Freeway on-ramp at University Ave. in Berkeley CA for 80 East and 580 West which is actually heading due north.

Isn't there another reason for rolling when in space? To keep the effects of the sun more averaged out? AFAIK, without rolling a craft, an object in space will be several hundred degrees on one side and extremely cold on the other. This isn't as big a deal with the ISS because it orbits the Earth every 90 minutes, whereas a craft in much higher orbit would be sitting in daylight much longer.

I would just add a tiny correction: In case of space shuttle, the roll after the launch is mostly due to the aerodynamic forces affecting the orbiter during the pitch. If the shuttle would to pitch tank first, more air would get between the orbiter and the tank increasing the pressure on the joints and possibly risking the integrity of the tiles.
As for communication, it is true that the antennas need to be pointed as best as possible, but during initial stages of the launch it is not that important because the Shuttle is near the ground. However, where it does matter is about 2 minutes before MECO, when the Shuttle is further up and downrange. This is the time when Shuttle does another roll to have the antennas pointed correctly before MECO and tank separation.
As for the astronauts, another important thing is the centrifugal force affecting them during the pitch. If the rocket were to both pitch and yaw, during the yaw motion astronauts would be thrown sideways, which is much less comfortable than being thrown into the seat when only pitching.
These are just minor details, you did an excellent job explaining a rather difficult subject in the most fun way possible. Thumbs up! :D

Soviet rockets use a rotating launch table because their ancestor, the German V-2 and (by more or less direct adoption) the Soviet R-7 ballistic missiles used their bodies for initial azimuth setting before launch.

Just for clarity: The ISS is in the orbit it's in because that's the inclination the Russians launched the first module into.  There was quite a debate as to what orbit it SHOULD be in before that module launched, but it was a done deal as soon as that module was in orbit because there was no way to change its orbit once it was up there.

Here's another potential reason to roll: triple core rockets (Delta 4 Heavy, Falcon 9 Heavy, Angara A3 (unflown)) have an opportunity to pitch up slightly and fly with an angle of attack -- thereby generating lift. They can be a giant flying wing. Of course this only works if the rocket is flat to the horizon.

However, I've never been able to confirm whether anyone actually does this. When I asked a senior SpaceX rep, he immediately went silent. So who knows.

Speaking of rocket azimuths...
In 2017 Russian "Fregat" booster has failed to deliver some communication sats to the orbit. The launch was happening on the new "Vostochny" cosmodrome, which has a starting azimuth of 168°. Target azimuth for lower stage was 354°. So the lower stage has decided prior to launch: "I need to rotate from 168 to 354, the fastest way is to rotate left by 174 degrees". Target azimuth after separation for upper stage, however, was 344°. So the upper stage has decided before launch: "I'm gonna rotate right by 170 degrees, it's the fastest way". Then after launch when the first stage completed the roll succesfully to the left, the upper stage calculated correctly that it is only 10° to the right from it's target direction, but it already decided on the ground that the fastest way to roll is to roll right... So it started to roll full 350° to the right, but didn't make it before second stage ignition and has gone to the wrong unstable orbit, ditching to the Atlantic Ocean shortly after.

The problem was in the code of booster's navigation system, but it always worked just fine before, because there was never such an unfortunate combination of azimuths.

Another great video, thanks Everyday Astronaut. One thing I'm not entirely sure about is the 20% increase of payload capacity of the Space Shuttle (that would be insane!!!!). A few months back I followed the entire open course "Engineering the Space Shuttle" at EdX, and the question "why the SS perfomed the roll maneuver" came up a few times. The engineers doing the talks gave 2 reasons:
1. They were re-using old Apollo launch pad, therefore they were subjected to their limitation and needed to be able to place the vehicle at the right attitude (with the roll maneuver).
2. The aerodynamic engineers figured it out that there was less stress on the orbiter when it was sitting underneath the main tank during the max Q phase (maximum areodynamic pressure), this was because (as you mentioned) the thrust was directed throught the center of the mass of the entire system, therefore the orbiter was somewhat skewed with respect to the flight path.

Funny story (I don't know if it's actually true, but it was stated on the aformentioned course): when Soviet launched their first and only Buran, they too did the roll maneuver. They didn't have to, because their launch pad was capable of giving the right attitude to the vehicles. So american engineers (after the collapse of the soviet union) asked russian engineers: why did you do that roll maneuver??? They replied: "Because you did it" :)
